facts.text: Gujarat Cotton Mills Co. Ltd. (Company) appointed Messrs. Pira Mal Girdhar Lal Co. (Agency Firm) as Managing Agents in 1938 via formal agreement dated February 28, 1938.
Agency Firm formed under partnership instrument dated February 26, 1938, with 11 partners: 3 Bombay Group, 8 Kanpur Group.
Agency Firm functioned as Managing Agents till September 1946, with variations in constitution.
In September 1946, shareholding: Kanpur Group 32,500 shares, Bombay Group 26,362 shares.

On September 7, 1946, 11 partners of Agency Firm agreed with Messrs. Chhuttu Ram Sons (Purchaser Firm) to sell 65,012 shares at Rs. 65 per share and resign Managing Agency before November 15, 1946, conditional on Purchaser Firm's appointment.
On October 30, 1946, Company General Body Meeting accepted Agency Firm's resignation and appointed Purchaser Firm as Managing Agents.
Purchaser Firm paid for shares at Rs. 65 per share.
Appellant is Hindu undivided family, former karta Dwarkanath, present karta Ramji Prasad, one of 11 partners in Kanpur Group, held 11,230 shares, received Rs. 65 per share.
Assessed to income-tax for 1948-49; ITO order dated June 5, 1952 assessed excess Rs. 2,98,909 as business income (difference between purchase and sale price).
Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed ITO order.
Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Delhi Bench, by order dated August 3, 1953 held receipt taxable as capital gains under s.12B, directed ITO to modify assessment.
Tribunal amended order on March 26, 1954 substituting 'processed' for 'assessed'.
Assessee contended before ITO: not liable under s.12B, or market value only for capital gains as Rs.65 included managing agency relinquishment.
ITO rejected contentions, redetermined capital gains but did not issue notice of demand under s.29.
Assessee applied to ITO on March 5, 1956 to issue notice under s.29 for appeal purposes; ITO refused.
Appeal to AAC under s.30 dismissed on March 8, 1957 as not maintainable.
Revision application to Commissioner under s.33A on September 27, 1956 against ITO order dated September 28, 1955.
Bombay High Court in case of Bombay Group held market value of shares for capital gains (Baijnath Chaturbhuj v. CIT). Attention drawn to Commissioner on November 18, 1957.
Commissioner dismissed revision on March 28, 1959: maintainability doubtful, no merits.
Writ petition No. 2071/1959 filed in Allahabad High Court on July 28, 1959 for certiorari to quash Commissioner and ITO orders, mandamus to issue fresh orders and notice under s.29.
High Court dismissed writ in limine: affidavit unsatisfactory, facts incomplete/confused, no merits.

legal_issues.text: Whether Commissioner's order under s.33A Income-tax Act, 1922 is quasi-judicial or administrative, amenable to certiorari under Art.226.
Whether revision under s.33A maintainable against ITO order where no appeal lies to AAC due to no demand notice under s.29.
Whether affidavit in writ petition complied with High Court rules and was sufficient.
Whether ITO bound to issue demand notice under s.29 after computing capital gains pursuant to Tribunal directions.

petitioner_arguments.text: Affidavit in writ petition was in accordance with law; High Court should have allowed rectification if defective.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Allahabad High Court Rules, Ch. XXII r.1(2)

petitioner_arguments.text: Revision under s.33A maintainable as appeal to AAC not maintainable; Commissioner should entertain and direct ITO to issue demand notice under s.29.
Facts same as Bombay High Court decision; Rs.65 per share included managing agency rights, so market value for capital gains.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Baijnath Chaturbhuj v. CIT, Bombay; s.12B Income-tax Act

respondent_arguments.text: Commissioner's order under s.33A is administrative, not amenable to certiorari.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Art.226 Constitution; CIT Punjab v. Tribune Trust (Privy Council)

court_reasoning.text: Art.226 confers wide power; certiorari issues to quasi-judicial acts, not administrative. Tests: legal authority, affects rights, duty to act judicially.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Commissioner under s.33A exercises quasi-judicial power as affects assessee rights, opportunity implied, similar to other statutes.

court_reasoning.text: s.33A revision on assessee application: call records, inquire, pass non-prejudicial order; affects rights, duty to act judicially.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Overrules High Court views relying on old Privy Council; even if administrative, mandamus lies against ITO for s.29 duty.

court_reasoning.text: Affidavit by Dhruva Das (relative/pairokar) specified sources: personal knowledge, records, legal advice; annexed documents; sufficient under rules.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court should have allowed amendment if defective; facts clear with documents.

court_reasoning.text: Revision maintainable under s.33A as no appeal to AAC (no s.29 notice); Bombay decision arguable on merits.
ITO must issue s.29 demand notice after tax due per order; failed statutory duty.

holdings.text: Commissioner's s.33A order is quasi-judicial, amenable to certiorari.
Revision under s.33A maintainable where no appeal lies to AAC due to absence of s.29 notice.
ITO bound to issue demand notice under s.29 when tax due.

precedents_cited.relevance: Scope of Art.226 wide, not limited to English prerogative writs.

precedents_cited.case_name: P.J. Irani v. State of Madras
Province of Bombay v. Kusaldas S. Advani
precedents_cited.relevance: Criteria for certiorari: legal authority, affects rights, duty to act judicially.

precedents_cited.case_name: R. v. Manchester Legal Aid Committee
Gullapalli Nageswara Rao v. Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation
precedents_cited.relevance: Certiorari against quasi-judicial act of administrative body.

precedents_cited.case_name: Board of High School and Intermediate Education, U.P. v. Ghanshyam Das Gupta
Board of Revenue, U.P. v. Sardarni Vidyawati

precedents_cited.relevance: s.33 administrative but not on certiorari issue; s.33A different.
Market value for capital gains in similar facts; arguable.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Capital gains taxation; demand notice mandatory; revision jurisdiction quasi-judicial where no appeal lies.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: High Court power to issue writs including certiorari and mandamus for quasi-judicial acts and statutory duties.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court set aside Allahabad High Court order dismissing writ petition in limine, issued writ of certiorari quashing Commissioner's order dated March 28, 1959 and writ of mandamus directing ITO to pass order and issue notice under s.29 in accordance with law.
outcome.relief_granted: Writs of certiorari and mandamus issued.

key_quotes.text: "It is well settled that a writ of certiorari can be issued only to quash a judicial or a quasi-judicial act and not an administrative act."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Prima facie the jurisdiction conferred under s.33A(2) of the Act is a judicial one."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Under this section, if a tax is due in consequence of an order from an assessee, the Income-tax Officer is under a duty to serve on him a notice of demand."
key_quotes.speaker: court
